SystemOutput:
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. Brian is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for congestive heart failure and hypertension, who presents today for follow-up of his chronic problems. The patient reports feeling out of sorts lately, with fatigue, lightheadedness, and bloating. These symptoms have been present for approximately five weeks. He has been experiencing shortness of breath during exertion and slight chest cramps that resolve within an hour. He also reports a slight cough. The patient has been adhering to his medications and monitoring his blood pressure at home. However, his diet has been off due to recent home renovations and eating out more frequently.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Positive fatigue and lightheadedness. No fever or chills.
• Cardiovascular: Positive bloating, shortness of breath on exertion, and slight chest cramps.
• Respiratory: Positive slight cough.
• Gastrointestinal: Denies nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Vital Signs: Blood pressure, heart rate, and oxygenation within normal limits.
• Neck: Jugular venous distention to 8 centimeters.
• Cardiovascular: 3/6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Respiratory: Fine crackles at the bases bilaterally.
• Extremities: 1+ pitting edema in lower extremities.

RESULTS

Chest X-ray: Fluid in lungs.
Echocardiogram (4 months ago): Pumping function reduced at 45%, mitral regurgitation present.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Congestive Heart Failure:
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient is retaining fluid, as evidenced by physical exam and chest x-ray.
   • Medical Treatment: Increase Lasix to 80 mg once a day. Patient to weigh themselves daily and report any weight gain or worsening symptoms. Order a new echocardiogram.

2. Hypertension:
   • Medical Reasoning: Blood pressure is well-managed at this time.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily. Patient to continue monitoring blood pressure at home and report any elevations through the patient portal.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CC:

Right knee pain.

HPI:

Ms. Thompson is a 43-year-old female who presents today for an evaluation of right knee pain. She reports that she was changing a light bulb on a ladder yesterday and had a stumble, twisting her knee while trying to catch her fall. She has been applying ice and taking ibuprofen, but it does not seem to help much. She has a history of atrial fibrillation and takes digoxin. She has a past surgical history of a rhinoplasty. She denies any allergies.

EXAM:

Examination of the right knee shows tenderness over the medial portion of the knee, over the medial meniscus area. Pain is elicited with flexion and valgus stressing of the leg. Normal sensation is present in the lower extremity. No calf pain reported.

RESULTS:

X-rays of the left knee obtained on today's visit show no fractures or dislocations. There is a small amount of fluid present, but overall alignment appears normal.

IMPRESSION:

Acute medial meniscus sprain or strain of the right knee.

PLAN:

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I have recommended we place her in a knee brace and provide crutches for temporary use. She will follow up in 1 week for reevaluation, and if not improved, we will consider an MRI. I will prescribe Motrin 800 mg, to be taken every 6 hours with food, for a 2-week supply.

All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Back pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Logan is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis, who presents today with back pain.

The patient states he was helping his daughter with heavy equipment and lifted some boxes too quickly, which were too heavy. This happened on Saturday morning, and he felt a pop in his lower back. He had to lie down for about an hour before the pain was relieved, and it has been stiff ever since. He has taken Tylenol, ibuprofen, and used icy heat on the spot, but it did not seem to help. He experienced tingling in his toes on his right foot until Sunday afternoon.

Regarding his diabetes, he admits to having a sweet tooth and not having the best diet recently. He plans to improve his eating habits.

Regarding his hypertension, he monitors his blood pressure readings at home during the week but tends to forget on weekends. He is taking his medication.

Regarding his osteoarthritis, it gets aggravated occasionally, but it has been manageable.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Denies weight loss. Denies fever, chills, nausea, or vomiting.
• Musculoskeletal: Endorses back pain. Denies chest pain.
• Neurological: Endorses tingling in toes on the right foot, which has resolved.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Cardiovascular: Grade 2/6 systolic heart murmur, stable.
• Musculoskeletal: Pain to palpation at the lumbar spine. Pain with flexion and extension. Negative straight leg raise.

Results:

Back X-ray is unremarkable with good bony alignment.

Hemoglobin A1c is elevated at 8.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Logan is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis, who presents today with back pain.

Acute lumbar strain.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient reports feeling a 'pop' and immediate pain while lifting heavy boxes. He has tried Tylenol and ibuprofen without significant relief.
• Medical Treatment: Initiate meloxicam 15 mg once daily. Continue icing the area and avoid strenuous activity.
• Specialist Referrals: Refer to physical therapy for further evaluation and treatment.

Diabetes type 2.
• Medical Reasoning: His recent hemoglobin A1c was 8, indicating the need for better control.
• Medical Treatment: Increase metformin to 1000 mg twice daily.
• Additional Testing: Repeat hemoglobin A1c in 6 months.

Hypertension.
• Medical Reasoning: Blood pressure readings are running on the high side.
• Medical Treatment: Increase lisinopril from 10 mg to 20 mg daily.

Osteoarthritis.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient is managing his knee arthritis well and does not require further workup at this time.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow-up in 2 weeks.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Annual exam and follow-up of chronic problems.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ralph is a 62-year-old male with a past medical history significant for depression, hypertension, and prior lobectomy. He presents for his annual exam.

Regarding his depression, he has been taking Prozac and reports no recent incidents. He states that his depression is well-managed.

Regarding his hypertension, he is taking Norvasc regularly during the business week but admits to occasionally forgetting on weekends. He reports that his blood pressure has been mostly okay.

The patient had a lobectomy a couple of years ago. He denies any significant shortness of breath except during high pollen season and when running in humid conditions. He runs 4-5 miles daily.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Ears, Nose, Mouth, and Throat: Endorses nasal congestion due to pollen.
• Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain, reports occasional chest pounding during exercise.
• Respiratory: Shortness of breath with exertion.
• Psychiatric: Endorses depression, well-managed with medication.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Cardiovascular: Slight 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally.
• Musculoskeletal: No lower extremity edema.
• Ears, Nose, Mouth, and Throat: Pain to palpation of sinuses.

VITALS REVIEWED

• Blood Pressure: 120/80 mmHg.

RESULTS

Electrocardiogram: Normal.
Chest X-ray: Normal, no concerning findings related to prior lobectomy.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Depression:
• Medical Reasoning: Well-managed with Prozac 20 mg daily.
• Medical Treatment: Continue current medication.
• Patient Education and Counseling: Refill prescription for Prozac 20 mg daily.

Prior Lobectomy:
• Medical Reasoning: No concerning findings on chest X-ray, patient exercising regularly and has good breathing function.
• Medical Treatment: No further follow-up with the surgeon needed.

Hypertension:
• Medical Reasoning: Blood pressure is well-controlled in the office, patient admits to occasional non-compliance on weekends.
• Additional Testing: Order an echocardiogram for the murmur.
• Medical Treatment: Continue current medication (Norvasc).

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CC:

Right index finger pain.

HPI:

Ms. Brooks is a 48-year-old female who presents today for an evaluation of right index finger pain after a skiing accident over the weekend. She reports that her finger was bent back while skiing over moguls.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS:

Miralax

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:

Constipation
Appendectomy at age 18

EXAM:

Examination of the right index finger shows tenderness over the distal phalanx. No tenderness over the proximal joint or metacarpophalangeal joint. Pain with flexion.

RESULTS:

X-rays of the right index finger obtained on today's visit show no fractures and everything lines up well.

IMPRESSION:

Right index finger contusion.

PLAN:

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I recommend an aluminum foam splint and a prescription for Motrin 600 mg every 6 hours for a week. If the pain does not improve, the patient is advised to call and return for a follow-up. All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Iron deficiency anemia.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Christina Cooper, a 65-year-old female, presents as a new patient referred by Diane Nelson for long-standing iron deficiency anemia. The patient was diagnosed with anemia in 12/2019 when she was unable to donate blood. She has been experiencing fatigue, feverishness, chills, shortness of breath, wheezing, headaches, and worsening anxiety and depression. The patient has a history of anemia since the age of 13 and had a hysterectomy in 1996.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
Iron deficiency anemia.
Hysterectomy (1996).

SOCIAL HISTORY

Alcohol consumption: once or twice a year.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

Ferrous sulfate 25mg tablets, twice daily.
Over-the-counter Vitamin B12.

PHYSICAL EXAM

General: Patient is alert and oriented.
Cardiovascular: Heart sounds normal.
Respiratory: Lungs clear to auscultation.
Abdomen: Soft, non-tender, no masses or organomegaly.

ASSESSMENT

Iron deficiency anemia.

PLAN

1. Upper endoscopy and colonoscopy: Schedule these procedures to assess for potential sources of anemia or GI bleed. If inconclusive, consider capsule endoscopy.

2. Hematologist referral: Send a referral to Dr. Flores, a hematologist, for further evaluation and management.

3. Iron supplementation: Continue ferrous sulfate 25mg twice daily with orange juice (for Vitamin C) for the next 8-12 weeks. Reassess blood work, including CBC, iron, ferritin, B12, and folate after this period.

INSTRUCTIONS

Schedule appointments for upper endoscopy, colonoscopy, and hematologist. Follow bowel prep instructions for colonoscopy. Call the clinic with any questions or worsening symptoms.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Worsening headaches and pituitary lesion.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. Bruce Ward is a 52-year-old male, referred by Dr. Henry Howard for consultation regarding a newly diagnosed pituitary lesion. The patient has been experiencing worsening headaches over the past few months, with no prior history of headaches. His past clinical history is unremarkable. Workup for headaches, including brain MRI and serology, revealed the pituitary lesion. The patient's pituitary hormone profile shows a low TSH, with all other results being normal. MRI of the brain with contrast reveals a pituitary lesion with elevation and compression of the optic chiasm. The patient reports a dull, nagging ache behind his eyes, with a gradual onset and worsening severity over the past three months. He denies any other symptoms, including fever, rashes, neck stiffness, numbness, weakness, or passing out. However, he has recently been bumping into door frames.

PAST HISTORY

Adopted, family medical history unknown.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Computer programmer, married for 25 years, recently bought a small house. Non-smoker, non-drinker, no recreational drug use.

EXAMINATION

The patient is alert and oriented to time, place, and person. Affect is appropriate and speech is fluent. Cranial nerve examination is grossly intact. No focal motor or sensory deficit in the upper or lower extremities. Visual acuity and eye movements are normal. Pupils are equal and reactive. Visual field testing reveals bitemporal hemianopia. Color vision is normal.

ASSESSMENT

Pituitary adenoma with optic chiasmal compression.

PLAN

1. Refer the patient to an eye doctor for a full exam and visual field test to map peripheral vision prior to surgery.
2. Schedule transsphenoidal surgery to excise and decompress the pituitary fossa.
3. Counsel the patient on the risks associated with surgery and anesthesia.
4. Monitor the patient's vision post-surgery for improvement.
5. Encourage the patient to call if they have any questions or concerns.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Chest pain and difficulty swallowing in October 2020.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Betty Hill is a 53 y.o. female who presents today for a new patient evaluation due to a referral from the ER for esophagitis. She experienced chest pain and difficulty swallowing in early October 2020, which resolved after four days. She has not had any recurrence of these symptoms since then. The patient had a normal cardiac workup in the ER.

The chest pain was located in the center of her chest, behind her breastbone, and was sharp in nature. The pain was worse with eating and she had difficulty swallowing during the episode. The patient reports that she was going through a stressful job transition at the time of the incident.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
Uterine fibroids.
Anemia.
Gallbladder removal.

SOCIAL HISTORY

No information provided.

FAMILY HISTORY

No known family history of GI problems.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

No information provided.

ALLERGIES

No known allergies.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Negative for weight loss, weight gain, headaches, bone pain, urinary symptoms, blood in the stools.
Positive for chest pain and difficulty swallowing in October 2020, which resolved after four days.

PHYSICAL EXAM

The patient has mild tenderness to light palpation in the upper abdominal quadrants. No other abnormalities noted.

ASSESSMENT

Possible etiologies for the patient's chest pain and difficulty swallowing include GERD, dyspepsia, esophagitis, musculoskeletal etiologies, and anxiety. The patient's symptoms occurred three months ago and have not recurred since then. It is suspected that she had an anxiety attack related to her job transition, with possible contribution from musculoskeletal etiologies.

PLAN

1. The patient has elected to self-monitor her symptoms and will call with any recurrence or change.
2. If the patient experiences any additional episodes of pain or other concerning symptoms, she will be scheduled for an EGD to evaluate her esophagus and stomach.
3. The patient will follow up as needed for any other GI complaints.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Kidney evaluation for Smith-Magenis Syndrome.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Katherine is a 22-month-old female with a history of Smith-Magenis Syndrome. She is a twin, born at 34 weeks and 3 days gestation, with a birth weight of 4 pounds, 8 ounces. She has had issues with feeding, temperature regulation, and severe reflux. She is currently in feeding therapy, occupational therapy, physical therapy, and will be starting speech therapy soon. She has seen multiple specialists, including a GI doctor, dietician, allergist, neurologist, orthopedic, ophthalmologist, and audiologist. The patient's geneticist mentioned potential kidney issues associated with the syndrome, prompting the current evaluation.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Smith-Magenis Syndrome.
Premature birth.
Feeding difficulties.
Reflux.

FAMILY HISTORY

No family history of kidney failure, dialysis, or transplant.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Well-nourished female, slightly fussy when examined. Eyes are small appearing. Mild hypotonia of the lower extremities in her arms. Normal external female genitalia.

ASSESSMENT

Smith-Magenis Syndrome with potential congenital anomalies of the kidney and urinary tract.

PLAN

1. Obtain a kidney ultrasound today to screen for congenital anomalies of the kidney and urinary tract.
2. If the ultrasound is normal, no further follow-up with nephrology is needed.
3. If the ultrasound is abnormal, determine next steps and future follow-up at the Town Center location, as the family lives in Dallas, Georgia.

INSTRUCTIONS

Complete kidney ultrasound today. Await results and follow up as needed based on the findings. Call the clinic with any questions or new symptoms.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right wrist pain and swelling.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Diana is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of right wrist pain and swelling. The onset of her pain began when she slipped on the stairs while doing laundry and tried to catch herself with her outstretched arms. The patient reports severe pain in her right wrist, rating it as a 9 out of 10. She has been icing her wrist, using an ace wrap, and taking ibuprofen, which provided minimal relief. The patient denies any previous injuries to her right arm.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Positive right wrist pain and swelling.
Neurological: Mild tingling in fingers, no numbness.

VITALS

BP: 140/70
HR: 80 bpm
RR: 20
Temp: 97.2°F
SPO2: Not reported.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Head/Neck: No adenopathy, thyromegaly, or carotid bruit.
CV: No murmur, rub, or gallop.
Pulmonary: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Extremities: Palpable pulses, no lower edema.
Upper extremities: Normal range of movement in left arm, pain and limited movement in right wrist.
Right wrist: Swelling, ecchymosis, tenderness on palpation, and bony crepitus.

RESULTS

X-ray of the right wrist reveals a Colles' fracture.

ASSESSMENT

Colles' fracture of the right wrist.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a discussion with the patient regarding her current symptoms and diagnosis. I have explained to her that her symptoms are consistent with a Colles' fracture. The patient will be provided with a brace for her right wrist. She will be scheduled for surgery as soon as possible. Post-surgery, the patient will be prescribed 50 mg of Ultram every six hours for pain management and will begin physical therapy a few weeks after surgery. The patient will wear the brace for six weeks and follow up in one month to assess her progress and discuss her upcoming vacation plans.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient is advised to follow the prescribed treatment plan and contact the office if her pain worsens or if she has any concerns.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right knee pain.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Hypertension, currently on 20 mg of Lisinopril.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports working on his property when the injury occurred.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies fever, chest pain, and shortness of breath.
Musculoskeletal: Reports right knee pain and swelling.

VITALS

Blood pressure: 150/70 mmHg
Heart rate: Not provided
Respiration: Not provided
No fever.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Respiratory
- Assessment of Respiratory Effort: Normal respiratory effort. Lungs clear bilaterally.

Cardiovascular
- Examination: Grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.
- Auscultation of Heart: Regular rate and rhythm. No gallops or rubs.

Musculoskeletal
- Examination: No clubbing, cyanosis, or edema.
- Right knee: Pain with flexion and extension. Pain to palpation on the medial aspect. No pain on the lateral aspect. Edema and effusion present.

RESULTS

X-rays of the right knee were obtained and reviewed. These reveal no fractures or bony abnormalities.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Right knee MCL strain.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient reports slipping and falling, resulting in knee pain and swelling. X-rays show no fractures or bony abnormalities.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Discussed the nature of the diagnosis and x-ray results. Advised the patient to avoid putting pressure on the knee and to have others help with yard work.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe ibuprofen 800 mg twice daily for pain and swelling. Provide a knee brace for support. Recommend icing the knee for 20 minutes, 3-4 times daily.

2. Hypertension management.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient has a history of hypertension and is currently on 20 mg of Lisinopril. Blood pressure was elevated at 150/70 mmHg during the visit.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Discussed the importance of diet and sodium intake in managing hypertension. Encouraged the patient to make dietary changes.
- Medical Treatment: Continue 20 mg of Lisinopril. Refer the patient to a nutritionist for assistance with dietary management.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up as needed.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left shoulder pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Wayne is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of left shoulder pain. The onset of his pain began 3 weeks ago, without any improvement. He denies any specific injury; however, he has been renovating his basement and putting in a new ceiling. He does not recall hitting or falling onto the left shoulder. The patient states he is very active and has experienced left shoulder pain before that usually resolves with Tylenol.

The patient reports significant pain with reaching, lifting, and overhead activities. The pain is constant. He states the pain is primarily located in the left shoulder and denies it radiates down into the left arm. The patient also reports difficulty sleeping secondary to the pain. He denies any numbness or tingling in his left arm or fingers. He has been taking Tylenol for pain, which provides partial relief.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports left shoulder pain. Neurological: Denies numbness or tingling.

VITALS

All vital signs are within the normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

MSK: Examination of the left shoulder: Limited active and passive ROM. Tenderness over the greater tuberosity of the humerus. No tenderness at the sternoclavicular or AC joints. Good hand grip. Neurovascularly intact distally. Capillary refill is less than 3 seconds. Sensation is intact to light touch distally.

RESULTS

X-rays of the left shoulder were obtained and reviewed today. These are normal and reveal no fracture or bony abnormalities.

ASSESSMENT

Left shoulder pain, likely rotator cuff tendinopathy.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with him regarding his current symptoms. I have explained that his x-rays did not reveal any signs of a fracture. I have recommended that we obtain an MRI of the left shoulder to evaluate for possible rotator cuff tendinopathy. The patient was provided with a referral to formal physical therapy. He will engage in a 6-to-8-week course in order to strengthen his left shoulder. I have also advised him to take Tylenol as needed for pain. If his symptoms do not improve, we may consider a steroid injection to the left shoulder.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up with me once the MRI results are available for review and further discussion.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left knee pain and instability.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Andrea is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of left knee pain and instability. The patient reports that her left knee occasionally gives out while walking, causing her to feel like she might fall. This occurs less than once a day and resolves quickly. The patient denies any history of injury to the left knee and has not taken any medications for pain. The patient is concerned about her upcoming trip, which will involve walking and line dancing, and is hesitant to participate due to her knee issues.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports left knee pain and instability. Denies right knee pain.

Cardiovascular: Reports taking blood pressure medication regularly.

Endocrine: Reports taking metformin for diabetes management.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vital Signs: Temperature 98.2, Pulse 72, Respirations 16, Blood Pressure 122/70.

Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, 2/6 systolic ejection murmur at left base.

Pulmonary: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.

MSK: Examination of the left knee: No ecchymosis, edema, or effusion. No pain to palpation. Full range of motion. Negative varus and valgus test.

RESULTS

Left knee x-ray: No evidence of fracture or bony abnormality.

ASSESSMENT

1. Left knee pain and instability, likely due to arthritis.
2. Hypertension.
3. Diabetes mellitus.

PLAN

1. For the left knee pain and instability, prescribe meloxicam 15 mg daily and consider initiating physical therapy to strengthen the surrounding muscles.
2. Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily for hypertension and order an echocardiogram to evaluate the heart murmur.
3. Order a hemoglobin A1C and lipid panel to assess diabetes management and potential adjustments to metformin dosage.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Cough and sore throat.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient is a 53-year-old female with a recent diagnosis of stage three non-small cell lung cancer. She is currently undergoing neo-adjuvant chemotherapy. Biopsy of a 4.4 cm left upper lobe nodule was positive for adenocarcinoma. Molecular testing is pending.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports good support from family members, friends, and nursing staff.

MEDICATIONS

Patient is currently on cisplatin and etoposide for chemotherapy.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Reports fatigue.
Respiratory: Reports a dry cough and sore throat.
Gastrointestinal: Denies difficulty swallowing or food getting stuck.
Psychiatric: Reports feeling emotionally and mentally strong.

VITALS

Oxygen saturation: Within normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Head and Face
- Examination: No pain to palpation of the frontal or maxillary sinuses.

Neck
- General Examination: No cervical lymphadenopathy or supraclavicular adenopathy.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs.

Respiratory
- Auscultation of Lungs: Crackles bilaterally.

Skin
- Examination: Erythema on the anterior side of the chest on the left side.

Lower Extremities
- Examination: No edema.

RESULTS

Chest X-ray: Mild radiation pneumonitis.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Non-small cell lung cancer.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient is currently undergoing neo-adjuvant chemotherapy with cisplatin and etoposide.
- Medical Treatment: Continue current chemotherapy regimen and radiation at 45 Gy. Repeat imaging after completion of treatment to assess tumor shrinkage and potential for surgical removal.

2. Radiation pneumonitis.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient's cough and crackles on lung exam are likely due to mild radiation pneumonitis.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe low-dose prednisone (40 mg daily for 5 days) to reduce inflammation and improve symptoms.

3. Sore throat and painful swallowing.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient's sore throat may be related to inflammation in the esophagus.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe lidocaine swish and swallow four times a day to help with pain relief and improve ability to eat and drink.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Low Immunoglobulin A (IgA) level.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Patient reports frequent colds in the wintertime that tend to linger. No recent history of abdominal infections or diarrhea.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Type 2 diabetes, recently started on metformin.

FAMILY HISTORY

No known family history of immune deficiencies.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient works at a family-owned donut shop.

TRAVEL HISTORY

Recent international travel to Zambia.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vitals: Within normal limits, no fever.
Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs.
Respiratory: Lungs clear, no wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
Neck: No lymphadenopathy.
Abdominal: Soft, non-tender.

LABORATORY RESULTS

Consistent with IgA deficiency.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. IgA deficiency.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient's lab work is consistent with an IgA deficiency. Additional blood work will be ordered to check for other immunodeficiencies.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Explained the nature of IgA deficiency and its potential impact on the patient's health. Advised the patient to watch for infections that do not resolve or are difficult to control, as well as any changes in their abdominal tract. Instructed the patient to inform healthcare providers of their IgA deficiency if they ever need blood products.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended assessment and plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right elbow pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Lawrence is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of right elbow pain. The patient has been experiencing right elbow pain for approximately 4 days. The pain is localized to the medial aspect of his elbow and radiates slightly into his forearm. He has been engaging in pottery activities during the pandemic, which he believes may have contributed to the pain. He denies any trauma or previous injury to the elbow. The patient has tried ibuprofen for pain relief with minimal success.

SOCIAL HISTORY

The patient has been engaging in pottery activities during the pandemic.

MEDICATIONS

The patient reports that he has been taking ibuprofen for pain relief.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports right elbow pain.

PHYSICAL EXAM

MSK: 
Examination of the right elbow: Pain to palpation along the medial aspect. Pain with pronation. Pain with resistance against flexion of the left wrist.

RESULTS

X-ray images of the right elbow were obtained and reviewed in the office today. These reveal no evidence of fracture or bony abnormality.

ASSESSMENT

Medial epicondylitis.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, we discussed the diagnosis of medial epicondylitis. The patient is advised to rest the elbow and wear a sling while awake. He is also instructed to apply ice to the elbow for 20 minutes three times a day and take ibuprofen 600 mg q.6 h. with food for a full week. The patient is advised to refrain from pottery activities for the next couple of weeks. A follow-up appointment is scheduled for one week to assess progress.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Emergency department follow up after a fall and chest pain.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports history of hypertension.

MEDICATIONS

Patient reports taking Bumex 2 mg once daily, Cozaar 100 mg daily, and Norvasc 5 mg once daily.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies sleep disturbance.
Cardiovascular: Reports chest pain and shortness of breath.
Respiratory: Denies dyspnea.
Genitourinary: Denies urinary incontinence.

VITALS

Blood Pressure: 128/72 mmHg
Temperature: 98.7 degrees F
Heart Rate: 72 bpm
Oxygen Saturation: 96%

PHYSICAL EXAM

Neck
- General Examination: No jugular venous distention.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Stable 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.

Musculoskeletal
- Examination: Trace lower extremity edema.

RESULTS

Echocardiogram reveals a preserved ejection fraction of 55%, abnormal diastolic filling, and mild-to-moderate mitral regurgitation.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Congestive heart failure.
- Medical Reasoning: This appears to have been caused by dietary indiscretion and uncontrolled hypertension.
- Patient Education and Counseling: I encouraged the patient to continue making dietary modifications, including limiting sodium intake. Referral placed for consult with a nutritionist for education and recommendations regarding diet.
- Medical Treatment: Continue with Bumex 2 mg once daily.

2. Hypertension.
- Medical Reasoning: This has been poorly controlled due to inconsistent compliance with medication and dietary indiscretion.
- Patient Education and Counseling: We discussed dietary modifications as noted above.
- Medical Treatment: Continue on Cozaar 100 mg daily and Norvasc 5 mg once daily. Renal artery ultrasound ordered to rule out any issues such as renal artery stenosis.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up in 3 months.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right-sided abdominal pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Russell is a patient who presents with sharp pain on the right side of his abdomen below his ribs for the last several days. The pain radiates to his lower abdomen and into his groin. The pain is intermittent and severe when it occurs. The patient reports burning sensation during urination and dark-colored urine. He has a history of kidney stones and a family history of kidney stones in his father. He has taken Tylenol for pain with minimal relief and reports feeling nauseated but has not vomited.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Gastrointestinal: Reports right-sided abdominal pain and nausea.

VITALS

Not provided.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Abdomen: No tenderness to palpation, no rebound or guarding, no peritoneal signs. Positive CVA tenderness on the right flank.

RESULTS

The CT scan of the abdomen revealed a 0.5 cm stone located in the proximal right ureter. There is no evidence of hydronephrosis.

ASSESSMENT

Acute nephrolithiasis (kidney stone).

PLAN

1. Encourage the patient to push fluids to facilitate urination and help pass the stone.
2. Prescribe oxycodone 5 mg every 6 to 8 hours as needed for pain. The patient may continue to take Tylenol for breakthrough pain.
3. Provide a strainer for the patient to strain his urine and monitor for the passage of the stone.
4. Order a basic metabolic panel, urinalysis, and urine culture to evaluate for any signs of infection.
5. Schedule a follow-up appointment in 1 to 2 weeks to check on the patient's progress. If symptoms have not improved, discuss further treatment options including lithotripsy or ureteroscopy.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient is instructed to contact the clinic if symptoms worsen or if there are any concerns.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Non-healing right foot ulcer.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Nicholas is a patient with a history of diabetes and diabetic neuropathy who presents today for evaluation of a non-healing right foot ulcer. He reports having the ulcer for approximately 6 weeks, which he first noticed after wearing a tight pair of shoes and going on a hike. The ulcer initially presented as a blister with stinging pain, but has since worsened with a foul smell, yellow drainage, and blackened tissue around the wound. He has been on antibiotics for 6 days, with some improvement in symptoms, but has recently experienced calf cramping and red streaks on his leg. He also reports difficulty catching his breath and a cough in the last two days. His blood sugars have been trending higher in the last two weeks, with occasional spikes up to 500.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports history of diabetes and diabetic neuropathy. His last hemoglobin A1c was 6.7.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient enjoys hiking and recently went on a hike with his wife.

MEDICATIONS

Patient reports taking antibiotics for the foot ulcer.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Reports fever of 99.7 and chills prior to starting antibiotics.
Respiratory: Reports cough and difficulty catching breath in the last two days.
Skin: Patient reports non-healing right foot ulcer with foul smell and yellow drainage.
Musculoskeletal: Reports calf cramping and red streaks on leg.

VITALS

Slight fever.
Blood pressure: Not provided
Heart rate: Not provided

PHYSICAL EXAM

Foot: 2x2 cm necrotic wound on right heel with sloughing tissue, cellulitis, and erythemia. No bony exposure. No palpable dorsalis pedis or posterior tibial pulses, but present via Doppler.
Vascular: Bilateral palpable femoral and popliteal pulses.

ASSESSMENT

1. Non-healing diabetic foot ulcer
2. Diabetes with recent poor blood sugar control
3. Possible cellulitis

PLAN

1. Order test to check blood supply for the wound.
2. Perform debridement of the wound in the office.
3. Obtain culture and consider adjusting antibiotic therapy based on results.
4. Monitor redness and swelling in the calf.
5. Schedule follow-up appointment in 7 days.
6. Recommend patient to follow up with endocrinologist for diabetes management.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Tick bite on right knee.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Patient reports spending time outdoors and recently went hunting. Patient noticed a tick bite on the right knee over a week ago, with burning sensation and discomfort.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies fever, chills, or body aches. Reports headache and general malaise since tick bite.
Respiratory: Denies cough or shortness of breath.
Musculoskeletal: Denies joint pain other than typical arthritic pain.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Hypertension: Controlled with lisinopril.
Diabetes: Controlled with metformin.

VITALS

Blood pressure: 122/70 mmHg
Heart rate: 67 bpm
Respiration: Not recorded
Temperature: 98.4°F

PHYSICAL EXAM

Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs, gallops, or rubs.
Respiratory: Clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Musculoskeletal: Full range of motion in right knee. Pain to palpation over right anterior knee.
Skin: Bull's-eye rash over right knee.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Possible Lyme disease.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient presents with tick bite and bull's-eye rash on right knee.
- Diagnostic Testing: Order Lyme titer and Western blot to confirm diagnosis.
- Medical Treatment: Start doxycycline 100 mg twice daily for 3 weeks.

2. Hypertension.
- Continue lisinopril 20 mg once daily.
- Order lipid panel to assess cholesterol levels.

3. Diabetes.
- Continue metformin 1000 mg twice daily.
- Order hemoglobin A1c to assess long-term blood sugar control.
- Order basic metabolic panel to monitor kidney function.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up as needed.
